dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, why are we, like, 15 times richer than our ancestors, yet still so utterly miserable? Is it just, uh, reptilian overlords from Xylar?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, why are we, like, fifteen times richer than our ancestors, yet still so utterly miserable? Is it just, uh, reptilian overlords from Xylar?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: How can we be at least 15 times richer than our pre-industrial Agrarian Age predecessors, and yet so unhappy?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Well, actually, that's one of the, um, more unusual explanations presented in this article we're looking at.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, actually, that's one of the, um, more unusual explanations presented in this article we're looking at.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: One explanation is that we are not wired for it: nothing in our heritage or evolutionary past prepared us to deal with a society of more than 150 people.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Unusual? You mean, completely ridiculous? Seriously? Lizard people?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Unusual? You mean, completely ridiculous? Seriously? Lizard people?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: It's, uh, framed as an explanation for why our modern societal systems are so hard to fine-tune. The idea is, like, we're not wired for societies larger than 150 people.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's, uh, framed as an explanation for why our modern societal systems are so hard to fine-tune. The idea is, like, we're not wired for societies larger than one hundred fifty people.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: One explanation is that we are not wired for it: nothing in our heritage or evolutionary past prepared us to deal with a society of more than 150 people.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, right. Because evolution prepared us for, what, cave paintings and grunting, but definitely not, um, iPhones and global supply chains. Got it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, right. Because evolution prepared us for, what, cave paintings and grunting, but definitely not, um, iPhones and global supply chains. Got it.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And these massive, complex systems we've built, like market economies and governments, they're supposedly, uh, subtly influenced by these 'Lizard People.'
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And these massive, complex systems we've built, like market economies and governments, they're supposedly, uh, subtly influenced by these 'Lizard People.'
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: We therefore have built massive societal machines comprising market economies, government and corporate bureaucracies, national and sub-national polities, cultural ideologies, and more.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: 'Subtly influenced.' So, not overtly, you know, wearing tiny lizard hats in parliament? Just, like, behind the scenes, pulling strings on our human sacrifices?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: 'Subtly influenced.' So, not overtly, you know, wearing tiny lizard hats in parliament? Just, like, behind the scenes, pulling strings on our human sacrifices?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: The article does mention, um, 'human sacrifice' in the context of systems needing to perform sub-tasks beyond their core mission, to preserve themselves for the 'reptilian masters.'
dialogue_turns.tts_text: The article does mention, um, 'human sacrifice' in the context of systems needing to perform sub-tasks beyond their core mission, to preserve themselves for the 'reptilian masters.'
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Instead, every system must perform multiple sub-tasks in addition to its core mission. These include providing sufficient resources to the people doing the work; coordinating things in the here and now; looking ahead from the here and now to the there and then; and maintaining the human participants focus on what the organization is for (its guiding philosophy).

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Human sacrifice. Right. And this is coming from an economist, Dan Davies, who the article calls a, quote, 'Xylarian operative,' unquote?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Human sacrifice. Right. And this is coming from an economist, Dan Davies, who the article calls a, quote, 'Xylarian operative,' unquote?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The economist Dan Davies has written a wonderful little book about our problematic creations.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yes, that's what it says. He wrote this book, 'The Unaccountability Machine,' about how big systems make terrible decisions.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yes, that's what it says. He wrote this book, 'The Unaccountability Machine,' about how big systems make terrible decisions.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In The Unaccountability Machine: Why Big Systems Make Terrible Decisions And How the World Lost Its Mind, Davies weaves together an argument from five separate threads.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Terrible decisions, because, like, little green men are telling them what to do? Or, uh, because people are just generally incompetent?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Terrible decisions, because, like, little green men are telling them what to do? Or, uh, because people are just generally incompetent?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: He argues it's about 'accountability sinks,' where things go wrong but no one can be held responsible, because, you know, the 'Lizard People' are influencing events.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: He argues it's about 'accountability sinks,' where things go wrong but no one can be held responsible, because, you know, the 'Lizard People' are influencing events.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The first is his observation that our world is rife with accountability sinks: places where things are clearly going wrong, but where there is no one to blame.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, rather than, say, poor management or, um, faulty algorithms, it's just, like, aliens. Convenient.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, rather than, say, poor management or, um, faulty algorithms, it's just, like, aliens. Convenient.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: And to fix it, he suggests exposing these 'reptilian overlords' and reviving 'management cybernetics,' which apparently involves, uh, rituals.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And to fix it, he suggests exposing these 'reptilian overlords' and reviving 'management cybernetics,' which apparently involves, uh, rituals.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Lastly, the best way to reform organizations so that they do not become unaccountability machines is to revive the post-World War II quasi-discipline of management cybernetics.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Rituals. Of course. For our, um, Xylar-ian friends. Is there, like, a secret handshake involved?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Rituals. Of course. For our, um, Xylar-ian friends. Is there, like, a secret handshake involved?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: The book, it's reviewed as a 'psychoanalysis for non-human intelligences.' Stafford Beer is the 'Sigmund Freud' of this.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: The book, it's reviewed as a 'psychoanalysis for non-human intelligences.' Stafford Beer is the 'Sigmund Freud' of this.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Reviewing The Unaccountability Machine in the Financial Times, Felix Martin describes Davies approach as a kind of psychoanalysis for non-human intelligences, with Stafford Beer as Sigmund Freud.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, that makes total sense. We need to get the aliens on the couch. Because that's definitely the key to understanding, um, our 'unaccountability machines.'
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, that makes total sense. We need to get the aliens on the couch. Because that's definitely the key to understanding, um, our 'unaccountability machines.'

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: The author does admit Davies doesn't give much of a real answer, just 'business-school blather,' but, uh, he defines the problem.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: The author does admit Davies doesn't give much of a real answer, just 'business-school blather,' but, uh, he defines the problem.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Unfortunately, Davies does not give us much of an answer. His book concludes with typical business-school blather. Nonetheless, he deserves credit for defining the task we face and pointing us toward a new intellectual path forward.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Defines the problem as alien overlords. I feel, like, profoundly enlightened. Or maybe just profoundly confused.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Defines the problem as alien overlords. I feel, like, profoundly enlightened. Or maybe just profoundly confused.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: We are left with a globe-spanning network of profoundly alien leviathans that boss us around and make us unhappy, even as they make us fabulously rich compared to previous generations.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Well, it is, uh, certainly a unique perspective on, um, organizational theory.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, it is, uh, certainly a unique perspective on, um, organizational theory.
